tool.name: OTB.PolygonClassStatistics
tool.description: Computes statistics on a training polygon set.
tool.command: $__tool_directory__/Code/openapi.py isArrayin False isArraymask False isArrayvec False isArrayelev.geoid False output_data_out $output_data_out name OTB.PolygonClassStatistics in $in mask $mask vec $vec field '$field' layer $layer elev.dem '$elev.dem' elev.geoid $elev.geoid elev.default $elev.default ram $ram prefer $prefer response $response outputType_out $OutputSection_out.outputType_out transmissionMode_out $OutputSection_out.transmissionMode_out

param.name: in
param.label: Support image that will be classified
param.help: Support image that will be classified The following data types are allowed in the txt file: png, tiff, jpeg

param.name: mask
param.label: Validity mask (only pixels corresponding to a mask value greater than 0 will be used for statistics)
param.help: Validity mask (only pixels corresponding to a mask value greater than 0 will be used for statistics) The following data types are allowed in the txt file: png, tiff, jpeg

param.name: vec
param.label: Input geometries to analyze
param.help: Input geometries to analyze The following data types are allowed in the txt file: png, tiff, jpeg

param.name: field
param.label: Name of the field carrying the class name in the input vectors.
param.help: Name of the field carrying the class name in the input vectors.

param.name: layer
param.label: Layer index to read in the input vector file.
param.help: Layer index to read in the input vector file.

param.name: elev.dem
param.label: This parameter allows selecting a directory containing Digital Elevation Model files. Note that this directory should contain only DEM files. Unexpected behaviour might occurs if other images are found in this directory.
param.help: This parameter allows selecting a directory containing Digital Elevation Model files. Note that this directory should contain only DEM files. Unexpected behaviour might occurs if other images are found in this directory.

param.name: elev.geoid
param.label: Use a geoid grid to get the height above the ellipsoid in case there is no DEM available, no coverage for some points or pixels with no_data in the DEM tiles. A version of the geoid can be found on the OTB website(https://gitlab.orfeo-toolbox.org/orfeotoolbox/otb-data/blob/master/Input/DEM/egm96.grd).
param.help: Use a geoid grid to get the height above the ellipsoid in case there is no DEM available, no coverage for some points or pixels with no_data in the DEM tiles. A version of the geoid can be found on the OTB website(https://gitlab.orfeo-toolbox.org/orfeotoolbox/otb-data/blob/master/Input/DEM/egm96.grd). The following data types are allowed in the txt file: octet-stream

param.name: elev.default
param.label: This parameter allows setting the default height above ellipsoid when there is no DEM available, no coverage for some points or pixels with no_data in the DEM tiles, and no geoid file has been set. This is also used by some application as an average elevation value.
param.help: This parameter allows setting the default height above ellipsoid when there is no DEM available, no coverage for some points or pixels with no_data in the DEM tiles, and no geoid file has been set. This is also used by some application as an average elevation value.

param.name: response
param.label: Response Type
param.help: Choose 'raw' for raw data or 'document' for document data.

section.name: OutputSection_out
section.title: Select the appropriate transmission mode for the output format and the output value

param.name: outputType_out
param.label: Output file to store statistics (XML format)
param.help: Output file to store statistics (XML format)

tool.help: The application processes a set of geometries intended for training (they should have a field giving the associated class). The geometries are analyzed against a support image to compute statistics : - number of samples per class - number of samples per geometryAn optional raster mask can be used to discard samples. Different types of geometry are supported : polygons, lines, points. The behaviour is different for each type of geometry : - polygon: select pixels whose center is inside the polygon - lines : select pixels intersecting the line - points : select closest pixel to the point
